KOI 3154 b
2MASS J19411149+4655136 b

planet.description: Kepler-47(AB) is a multiplanetary system orbiting a binary star. This is the first system of its kind. One of the binary stars is a Sun-like star, the other one is roughly one-third the size of the Sun. The orbital period of the binary is 7.45 days.
planet.imagedescription:
An artists depiction of the Kepler-47 system.
Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/T. Pyle

One of the binary stars is a Sun-like star, the other one is roughly one-third the size of the Sun. The orbital period of the binary is 7.45 days. The outer planet Kepler-47(AB) c is located in the habitable zone where liquid water could exist.

KOI 904.03
KID 8150320
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered by the Kepler spacecraft. It transits its host star every 42.15 days for 5.0617 hours. Periodic transit timing variations confirm its planetary nature.

planet.name: WTS-1 b
planet.description: The Hot Jupiter WTS-1 b is the first extrasolar planet found by the WFCAM Transit Survey. The observations were made at the 3.8-m United Kingdom Infrared Telescope and the Hobby-Eberly Telescope. The planet has one of the largest radius anomalies among the known Hot Jupiters its mass range.

planet.name: WASP-90 b
1SWASP J210207.70+070323.7 b
2MASS 01463185+0242019 b
planet.description: This hot Jupiter has been discovered by the WASP transit survey and confirmed by radial velocity measurements. It is one of the most irradiated planets known. The host star is evolved and has a post main sequence radius.

planet.name: MOA-2010-BLG-073L b
2MASS J18101138-2631226 b
planet.description: The planet MOA-2010-BLG-073L b was discovered by the Microlensing Observations in Astrophysics (MOA) survey. In a microlensing event like this, the light from a source star is bent and magnified by a foreground star and a planet. In this case the source star was previously known to be photometrically variable.

planet.name: BD+15 2940 b
HIC 78407 b
planet.description: The planet BD+15 2940 b was discovered by the Penn State - Torun Planet Search (PTPS) using ground based spectrometer. It is the closest-in planet around a giant star. It might soon be swallowed by the star as a consequence of stellar evolution.

planet.name: Kepler-65 b
KOI-85 b
KIC 5866724 b
planet.description: This object was found by the Kepler mission. It is very likely that the transit signals are caused by planets because of statistical arguments, the fact that the system seems to host three planets and significant transit timing variations. The outer two planets are near a 7:5 commensurability.

planet.name: Kepler-65 c
KOI-85 c
KIC 5866724 c
planet.description: This object was found by the Kepler mission. It is very likely that the transit signals are caused by planets because of statistical arguments, the fact that the system seems to host three planets and significant transit timing variations. The planet Kepler-65 c is near a 7:5 commensurability with the planet Kepler-65 d.

planet.name: Kepler-65 d
KOI-85 d
KIC 5866724 d
planet.description: This object was found by the Kepler mission. It is very likely that the transit signals are caused by planets because of statistical arguments, the fact that the system seems to host three planets and significant transit timing variations. Only an upper mass limit is known for this system (10 Earth masses). It is near a 7:5 commensurability with the planet Kepler-65 c.

planet.name: WASP-66 b
planet.description: This planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team.

planet.name: BD-061339 b
HIP 27803 b
planet.description: The star BD-061339 hosts two planets. The inner planet is a super-Earth (assuming sin(i)=1). It might be tidally locked due to its proximity to the host star. The planet was discovered with the European HARPS instrument.

planet.name: BD-061339 c
HIP 27803 c
planet.description: The star BD-061339 hosts two planets. The outer planet has about three Neptune masses and is located in the habitable zone. However, the planet has most likely no solid surface on which liquid water could exist. The planet was discovered with the European HARPS instrument.

planet.name: Kappa And b
planet.description: Kappa Andromedae b is an extrasolar planet or possibly low-mass brown dwarf. Astronomers have directly imaged it using the Subaru telescope on Hawaii. An object is called a planet when it is not able to fuse hydrogen in its core. Kappa Andromedae b is very close to the theoretical limit of 13 Jupiter masses.
planet.imagedescription:
Image of the star Kappa Andromedae and the planet or brown dwarf Kappa Andromedae (top left).
Credit: J. Carson et al 2012.
planet.name: Kappa Andromedae b
HD 37605 b
planet.description: The planetary system HD 37605 hosts at least two planets. The inner planet is on a 55 day orbit with a very high eccentricity of 0.6767. This planet was discovered in 2004. In 2012, another planet on a 2720 day orbit was announced. In contrast to the inner planet, HD 37605 c is on an almost circular orbit. This leads to interesting speculations on the origin of the planetary system.

planet.name: HD 37605 c
planet.description: The planetary system HD 37605 hosts at least two planets. The inner planet is on a 55 day orbit with a very high eccentricity of 0.6767. This planet was discovered in 2004. In 2012, another planet on a 2720 day orbit was anounced. In contrast to the inner planet, HD 37605 c is on an almost circular orbit. This leads to interesting speculations on the origin of the planetary system.

planet.name: HD 215456 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 215456 c
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 100546 b
planet.description: HD 100546 is a Herbig Ae/Be star. High contrast observations of the circumstellar disk reveal an emmision source at a distance of 68 astronomical units. The most likely explanation is a planet in the process of forming. If confirmed, HD100546 b would be a unique laboratory to study the formation process of a new planetary system, with one giant planet currently forming in the disk and a second planet possibly orbiting in the disk gap at a smaller separation.
planet.imagedescription:
This artist's impression shows the formation of a gas giant planet in the ring of dust around the young star HD 100546. This system is also suspected to contain another large planet orbiting closer to the star. The newly-discovered object lies about 70 times further from its star than the Earth does from the Sun. This protoplanet is surrounded by a thick cloud of material so that, seen from this position, its star almost invisible and red in colour because of the scattering of light from the dust.
Credit: ESO/L. Calcada

planet.name: Kepler-63 b
KIC 11554435 b
KOI 63 b
KOI 63.01
KOI-63 b
KOI-63.01
planet.description: Kepler-63 b orbits a Sun-like star every 9.43 days. The host star has a large and persistent polar starspot and a high sky-projected obliquity of 104 degrees. Polar star spots have been predicted in simulations of magnetic activity of young Sun-like stars.

planet.name: HD 109271 b
HIP 61300 b
planet.description: This planet was discovered with the European HARPS instrument. The system hosts at least two planetary companions. The architecture of this system is very similar to that of HD 698430. That might suggest that certain architectures are preferred in Nature.

planet.name: HD 109271 c
HIP 61300 c
planet.description: This planet was discovered with the European HARPS instrument. The system hosts at least two planetary companions. The architecture of this system is very similar to that of HD 698430. That might suggest that certain architectures are preferred in Nature.

planet.name: KOI-55 b
planet.description: The planet KOI-55 b is orbiting a former red-giant star. It probably survived deep immersion in the red-giant's envelope. When the star ran out of hydrogen after about 10 billion years, it swelled dramatically. Our own sun will also undergo this phase and expand as far as the Earth's orbit. The planet that we see today in the KOI-55 system might just be the dense core of an evaporated giant planet which survived the death of its sun. The planet was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft but is not transiting. It is inferred from brightness pulsations.

planet.name: KOI-55 c
planet.description: The planet KOI-55 c is orbiting a former red-giant star. It probably survived deep immersion in the red-giant's envelope. When the star ran out of hydrogen after about 10 billion years, it swelled dramatically. Our own sun will also undergo this phase and expand as far as the Earth's orbit. The planet that we see today in the KOI-55 system might just be the dense core of an evaporated giant planet which survived the death of its sun. The planet was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft but is not transiting. It is inferred from brightness pulsations.

planet.name: PH-2 b
KIC 12735740 b
2MASS 19190326+5157453 b
Planet Hunters 2 b
planet.description: The exoplanet PH-2 b was discovered by citizen scientists using an online tool at planethunters.org. The planet is a gas giant and could be located in the star's habitable zone. The system might also have a faint binary companion.
planet.imagedescription:
Artistic rendition of a sunset view from the perspective of an imagined Earth-like moon orbiting the giant planet, PH2 b.
Image Credit: H. Giguere, M. Giguere/Yale University

planet.name: WASP-55 b
planet.description: This planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team.

HD 190360 A b

planet.description: The A component of the star system Gliese 777 hosts at least two planets. With 6.7 billion years, the host star is much older than our Sun. The binary companion is a dim red dwarf orbiting at a distance of 3000 astronomical units.

HD 190360 A c

planet.name: CFBDSIR2149
planet.description: This planet is an orphan planet, which means it is not orbiting any star. Some people therefore argue that it should not be called a planet. The object is associated with the AB Doradus moving group which allows astronomers to determine its age and therefore its mass.

Artist's impression of the free-floating planet CFBDSIR J214947.2-040308.9
ESO/L. Calcada/P. Delorme/Nick Risinger (skysurvey.org)/R. Saito/VVV Consortium

planet.name: HD 66141 b
HIP 39311 b
HR 3145 b
planet.description: HD 66141 b is a massive planet orbiting an evolved K giant. The star is approximately as massive as our Sun but more than 20 times larger. It has exhausted its hydrogen supply and has begun fusing helium into oxygen and carbon in its core.

planet.name: HD 204941 b
planet.description: HD 204941 b was found with the European High Accuracy Radial velocity Planet Searcher (HARPS) which can reach sub-meter-per-second precision. The host star shows evidence for long-term solar-like magnetic cycles.

planet.name: HD 97658 b
planet.description: Models suggest that HD 97658 b has a rocky core that is enveloped in an atmosphere composed of lighter elements. The planet's host star is the second brightest known to host a transiting super-Earth which facilitates folllow-up observations.

planet.name: KOI-285 b
KOI-285 1
planet.description: This planet was discovered by the Kepler spacecraft. The planet is part of a multiplanetary system. Its planetary nature has been confirmed using transit timing variations which arise because the planets in one system pull on each other and slightly alter the transit times.

planet.name: KOI-285 c
KOI-285 2
planet.description: This planet was discovered by the Kepler spacecraft. The planet is part of a multiplanetary system. Its planetary nature has been confirmed using transit timing variations which arise because the planets in one system pull on each other and slightly alter the transit times.

planet.name: KOI-0285 d
KOI-0285 03
planet.description: This is a Kepler Object of Interest from the Q1-Q12 dataset. It has been flagged as a possible transit event but has not been confirmed to be a planet yet.

2MASS J04150149-2206591 b
TYC 5889-271-1 b
GSC 05889-00271 b
planet.description: WASP-78b is a highly bloated Jupiter-mass exoplanet. It is orbiting an F-type star and was discovered and analyzed using WASP, TRAPPIST and CORALIE data. It is one of the hottest known exoplanets with an equilibrium temperature of 2350 degrees Kelvin.

planet.name: Kepler-22 b
KIC10593626 b
planet.description: The planet Kepler-22b has been discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. It is orbiting the solar type Kepler target star KIC10593626. This puts it in the habitable zone with an equilibrium temperature of minus 11 degrees Celsius (plus 11 degrees Fahrenheit). If the planet has an atmosphere similar to that of Earth then the surface temperature is 22 degrees Celsius (71 degrees Fahrenheit). Kepler-22b is the smallest radius planet known to orbit in the habitable zone of any star other than the Sun.
planet.imagedescription:
This is an artist's conception illustrating the exoplanet Kepler-22b. The planet lies in the habitable zone of a Sun-like star KIC10593626. The habitable zone around a star is usually defined to be the zone in which liquid water, a requirement for life on Earth, could persist.
Scientists do not yet know if the planet has a predominantly rocky, gaseous or liquid composition. It's possible that the world would have clouds in its atmosphere, as depicted here in the artist's interpretation.
Credit: NASA/Ames/JPL-Caltech

star.name: Qatar-1
GSC 04240-00470
star.planet: Qatar-1 b 2MASS J20133160+6509433 b GSC 04240-00470 b Confirmed planets 1.33 x 1.164 1.42002504 0.02343 0.0 83.82 2445518.4102 transit -8.4 13/04/02 2010 1389 Qatar-1 b orbits a metal-rich K-dwarf, one of the faintest around which a planet has been discovered by ground based surveys. Measurements of the Rossiter-McLaughlin effect show that the sky-projected obliquity between the orbital plane of the planet and the star's rotation axis is only a few degrees.

planet.name: Kepler-29 b
KOI 738.01
KIC 10358759 b
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. Its host star gets periodically fainter whenever the planet is in front of the star. Because there are multiple phenomena that can create a signal that looks similar to a planetary transit, the candidates have to be confirmed with another method. For Kepler-29 the planetary nature of the companions has been confirmed by transit timing variations, caused by other planets in the system, and a stability analysis. However, the mass of the planets is not well constrained yet.

2MASS 07350197+1749482

These planets might be inflated because some of the stellar irradiation is somehow transported into the planetary interior. Excess energy could also be injected into the interior by tides if the planet was initially on an eccentric orbit.

A signal of a sixth planet has also been reported but should be taken with a grain of salt as it might correlate with chromospheric emission from the star. If the signal is a genuine signal of planetary origin, then this super-Earth might be habitable as it could support liquid water on its surface.

planet.description: The planetary system HD 82943 consists of two planets in a 2:1 mean motion resonance. Both resonant angles are librating around zero. The orbital parameters are based on 10 years of radial velocity measurements with the Keck telescope.

planet.name: Kepler-67 b
planet.description: Kepler-67 b is orbiting a Sun-like star in the billion-year-old open cluster NGC6811. It demonstrates that small planets can form and survive in a dense cluster environment. The frequency of planets around stars in open cluster and field stars in the Milky Way are approximately the same.

planet.name: HAT-P-43 b
2MASS 08354217+1012239 b

planet.name: beta Pic b
planet.imagedescription: This image shows the planet Beta Pictoris b. It has been optained with NACO on VLT. The star has been masked out to enable the viewer to see clearly the planet. Credit: ESO.

planet.name: Gliese 667 C b
GJ 667 C b
HR 6426C b
planet.description: Gliese 667 is a nearby triple star system in the constellation Scorpius, about 22 light years away. The star Gliese 667 C hosts at least six planets. Three of them, all Super-Earths, are located in the habitable zone. The habitable zone is so densely packed that any additional planet is likely to destabilize the system. This planet, Gliese 667 C b, is located too close to the star and not in the habitable zone.
planet.imagedescription:
This artist's impression shows the view from the exoplanet Gliese 667 C d looking towards the planet's parent star (Gliese 667 C). In the background to the right the more distant stars in this triple system (Gliese 667 A and Gliese 667 B) are visible and to the left in the sky one of the other planets, the newly discovered Gliese 667 Ce, can be seen as a crescent. A record-breaking three planets in this system are super-Earths lying in the zone around the star where liquid water could exist, making them possible candidates for the presence of life. This is the first system found with a fully packed habitable zone.
Credit: ESO/M. Kornmesser

planet.name: Gliese 667 C h

HR 6426C h
planet.description: Gliese 667 is a nearby triple star system in the constellation Scorpius, about 22 light years away. The star Gliese 667 C hosts at least six planets. Three of them, all Super-Earths, are located in the habitable zone. The habitable zone is so densely packed that any additional planet is likely to destabilize the system. This planet, Gliese 667 C h has yet to be confirmed.

planet.description: The star HAT-P-7 is located in the constellation Cygnus and in the field of view of the Kepler spacecraft. Measurements of the Rossiter-McLaughlin effect suggest that this planet is in a retrograde orbit. Retrograde orbits are difficult to explain with standard disk migration. Planet-planet scattering or the Kozei effect are able to produce retrograde orbits.

NASA has given the planetary system the alternative identifier UGA-1785 in honor of the University of Georgia.

KOI-245 c

GJ 436 b
Gj 436 b
Gl 436 b
planet.description: The star Gliese 436 is located in the constellation Leo. Due to tidal forces the planet Gliese 436b is expected to circularise on short timescales. It might be perturbed by an additional planet in the system.

planet.name: Gliese 436 c
GJ 436 c
Gj 436 c
Gl 436 c
UCF-1.01
planet.description: The star Gliese 436 is located in the constellation Leo. While observing the already known planet Gliese 436 b with the Spitzer Space Telescope, astronomers have discovered an additional transiting planet Gliese 436 c. The planet is also known as UCF-1.01. There might be even more planets in the system.
planet.imagedescription:
This artist's concept shows what astronomers believe is an alien world just two-thirds the size of Earth. It was identified by NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope. UCF-1.01 might be the nearest world to our solar system that is smaller than our home planet.
Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech

planet.name: HD 80606 b
Struve 1341 B b
planet.description: The star HD 80606 (also known as Struve 1341 B) is part of a binary star system with a separation of 1200 astronomical units. It hosts an extrasolar planet on a highly elliptical orbit. Because of the high eccentricity the temperature of the planet's surface can rise from 800K to 1500K in just 6 hours.

planet.name: KOI-254 b
planet.description: KOI-254 b was originally discovered by the Kepler spacecraft. It has now been confirmed to be a planet by radial velocity measurements, adaptive optics imaging and spectroscopy. The host star is an M-type dwarf star, just over half the size of our own sun. KOI-254 b is the first hot Jupiter that has been found around such a low mass star.

planet.description: Gliese 328 b is an eccentric two Jupiter-mass planet with an orbital period of eleven years. The discovery is based on ten years' worth of radial velocity data from the Hobby-Eberly and Harlan J. Smith telescopes at McDonald Observatory, and from the Keck Telescope at Mauna Kea. It is currently the most massive, longest-period planet discovered around a low-mass dwarf.

planet.name: Gliese 1214 b
GJ 1214 b
Gj 1214 b
Gl 1214 b
planet.description: Gliese 1214 is a red dwarf in the constellation Ophiuchus only 40 light years away. The planet was found with a 40cm telescope and commercially available cameras. New observations from NASA's Hubble Space Telescope show that it is a waterworld enshrouded by a thick, steamy atmosphere. GJ1214b represents a new type of planet, like nothing seen in our solar system or any other planetary system currently known.
planet.imagedescription:
This image shows an artist's view of the planet Gliese 1214 b in front of its host star.
Credit: NASA, ESA, and D. Aguilar (Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics).

planet.name: KIC 8435766 b
Kepler-78 b
2MASS 19345800+4426539 b
TYC 3147-188-1 b
planet.description: The Earth-sized planet KIC 8435766 b, also known as Kepler-78 b, was identified in the Kepler database and confirmed to be a transiting planet (as opposed to an eclipsing binary) through the absence of ellipsoidal or radial velocity variations. The planet has a dayside temperature of 2300K-3100K. The planet's density is similar to that of Earth, suggesting a composition of rock and iron.

The planet is not habitable but its sky would be starrier than what we see from Earth.

planet.description: MOA-2010-BLG-328 is a planetary microlensing event. Multiple fits (including one with source orbital motion, xallarap) can explain the system. The mass of the companion might therefore change. However, all fits clearly show the presence of a planery mass object: MOA-2010-BLG-328L b.

planet.name: HD 7199 b
planet.description: HD 7199 b was found with the European High Accuracy Radial velocity Planet Searcher (HARPS) which can reach sub-meter-per-second precision. The host star shows evidence for long-term solar-like magnetic cycles.

planet.name: WASP-67 b
planet.description: This planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team.

planet.name: 14 And b
planet.description: 14 Andromedae is an evolved star in the constellation of Andromeda. It was formerly an A-type dwarf.

planet.name: Gliese 581 b
GJ 581 b
Gj 581 b
Gl 581 b
planet.description: Gliese 581 is a red dwarf in the constellation Libra. It is the 89th closest star to the Solar System. In late 2010, US astronomers annoucent a planet in the habitable zone. This statement has been challenged by the European HARPS team. Gliese 581 c is likely to have a runaway greenhouse effect. A radio message has been sent to Gliese 581 in 2008 and will reach the star system in 2029.

This statement has been challenged by the European HARPS team. Gliese 581 c is likely to have a runaway greenhouse effect. A radio message has been sent to Gliese 581 in 2008 and will reach the star system in 2029.

planet.name: Gliese 581 d
GJ 581 d
Gj 581 d
Gl 581 d
planet.description: Gliese 581 is a red dwarf in the constellation Libra. It is the 89th closest star to the Solar System. In late 2010, US astronomers annoucent a planet (Gliese 581f) in the habitable zone. This statement has been challenged by the European HARPS team. Gliese 581 d might be habitable according to a paper by Wordsworth et al. (2011) who studied the system using three dimensional climate simulations. A radio message has been sent to Gliese 581 in 2008 and will reach the star system in 2029.

Gl 581 e
planet.description: Gliese 581 is a red dwarf in the constellation Libra. It is the 89th closest star to the Solar System. In late 2010, US astronomers annoucent a planet in the habitable zone. This statement has been challenged by the European HARPS team. Gliese 581 c is likely to have a runaway greenhouse effect. A radio message has been sent to Gliese 581 in 2008 and will reach the star system in 2029.

planet.name: Gliese 581 f
GJ 581 f
Gj 581 f
Gl 581 f
planet.description: Gliese 581 f is an unconfirmed planet. Its discovery was announced in 2010 by the Lick-Carnegie Exoplanet Survey. However an analysis by the European HARPS team concluded that the system is unlikely to contain a planet with the quoted characteristic.

planet.name: Gliese 581 g
GJ 581 g
Gj 581 g
Gl 581 g
planet.description: Gliese 581 g is an unconfirmed planet. Its discovery was announced in 2010 by the Lick-Carnegie Exoplanet Survey. However an analysis by the European HARPS team concluded that the system is unlikely to contain a planet with the quoted characteristic. The planet attracted a lot of attention because of its location near the middle of the habitable zone.

planet.name: Kepler-25 b
KIC 3231341 b
KOI 244.01
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. Its host star gets periodically fainter whenever the planet is in front of the star. Because there are multiple phenomena that can create a signal that looks similar to a planetary transit, the candidates have to be confirmed with another method. For Kepler-25 the planetary nature of the companions has been confirmed by transit timing variations, caused by other planets in the system, and a stability analysis. However, the mass of the planets is not well constrained yet.

planet.name: WASP-98 b
1SWASP J035342.90-341941.7 b

planet.description: This is a hot Jupiter discovered by the WASP team.

planet.name: Gliese 876 b
GJ 876 b
Gj 876 b
Gl 876 b
planet.description: Gliese 876 is a red dwarf only 15 light years from Earth in the constellation Aquarius. The orbits of the outer three planets are locked in a Laplace reasonance. This resonance is also present in the moons of Jupiter: Io, Europa, Ganymede. This strong dynamical interaction leads to interesting conclusions about the formation history of the system. It is a very strong indication that the planets migrated in the protoplanetary disk to their current position and got locked into mean motion resonances during that process.

Artist's impression of Gliese 876 e, a member of a multi-planetary system. The illustration shows the planet from the perspective of a hypothetical moon orbiting.

planet.name: HAT-P-8 b
HAT-P-8 A b
2MASS J22520985+3526495 b
TYC 2757-1152-1 b
planet.description: The extrasolar planet HAT-P-8b is orbiting the star HAT-P-8 in the constellation of Pegasus. It is the 11th planet discovered by the HATNet project. Variations in the optical bands may indicate the presence of strong absorbers such as TiO or VO gases. The host star is part of a hierarchical triple system.

planet.name: MOA-bin-1 b
planet.description: This planet has been discovered in data from the 2006-2007 MOA project by Bennett et al (2012). It is the first planetary event in which the stellar host is only detected through binary microlensing events. Note that the discovery paper has not been published in a peer-reviewed journal yet.

planet.name: CoRoT-5 b
CoRoT-Exo-5 b
CoRoTID 102764809 b
planet.description: CoRoT 6 is an F-type star in the constellation Monoceros.

planet.name: KOI-889 b
KIC-757450 b
2MASS 19243302+3634385 b
planet.description: This planet was discovered with the Kepler telescope and confirmed with the SOPHIE and HARPS-N spectrographs. The planet is on a very eccentric orbit and at the boundary between regimes where the tides from the host star can explain circularization and where tidal effects are negligible.

planet.name: Kepler-36 b
KOI 277.01
KIC 11401755 b
2MASS 19250004+4913545 b
planet.description: The Kepler-36 system consists of a pair of planets which are twenty times more closely spaced than any adjacent pair of planets in the Solar System. Their densities differ significantly. Kepler-36 b is most likely a super-Earth, whereas Kepler-36 c might resemble Neptune.
planet.imagedescription:
This artist's conceptions shows Kepler-36 c as seen from the surface of the neighboring planet Kepler-36 b.
Image credit: Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics/David Aguilar.

The planet was first announced in 2012.

planet.name: OGLE-2012-BLG-0026L b
planet.description: This multi-planetary system was discovered during a high-magnification gravitational microlensing event. Both planets are located beyond the snow-line, an important clue for planet formation models.

planet.name: OGLE-2012-BLG-0026L c
planet.description: This multi-planetary system was discovered during a high-magnification gravitational microlensing event. Both planets are located beyond the snow-line, an important clue for planet formation models.

planet.name: WASP-61 b
planet.description: This planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team.

planet.name: KIC 6185331 b
planet.description: This planet was not flagged as a potential planet candidate by the Kepler data pipeline. Citizen scientists discovered the transit simply by looking at many light curves by eye using the online tool at planethunters.org.

planet.name: iota Draconis b
HIP 75458 b
HD 137759 b
planet.description: The planet iota Droconis b has a very eccentric orbit. Kanet et al (2010) report a transit probability that is higher than that of a typical Hot Jupiter in a 5 day orbit. However, the weakness of the transit signal requires space-based observations to achieve an unambiguous transit detection.

planet.name: HD 204313 c
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: 70 Vir b
planet.description: The star 70 Virginis is located in the constellation Virgo and starting to evolve into the subgiant phase. It has a dust disc at 3.4 AU.

planet.name: HAT-P-3 b
TYC 3466-00819-1 b
2MASS J13442258+4801432 b
planet.description: The young and metal rich star HAT-P-3 is located in the constellation Ursa Major. The planet HAT-P-3 b has about 75 Earth masses worth of heavy elemetns.

planet.name: GQ Lup b
planet.description: GQ Lupi b is a directly imaged planet or brown dwarf orbiting the star GQ Lupi in the constellation Lupus.
planet.imagedescription: This image show the star GQ Lupi and a planetary companion on the right. It was taken with NOCA on VLT. The planetary companion is about 250 dimmer than the star. Credit: ESO.

planet.name: 14 Her b
planet.description: The star 14 Herculis is only 59 light years away in the constellation Hercules. However, because it is an orange dwarf star it can not be seen with the naked eye. There is only one confirmed planet in the system, but a dynamical analysis suggests that they might be two planets locked in a 4:1 mean motion resonance.

planet.name: HD 213240 A b
planet.description: The binary star system HD 213240 consists of the components A and C. The letter B was already used by the WDS survey from 1901 to describe another object. However, it turns out that the B component is not physically associated with the binary. The planet orbiting the A component was discovered in 2001 by Santos and collaborators.

planet.name: HD 108863 b
planet.description: The star HD 108863 hosts a Jupiter-like planet. It was discovered as part of a Doppler survey at the Keck Observatory.

planet.name: Gliese 504 b
GJ 504 b
HIP 64792 b
HD 115383 b
planet.description: Gliese 504 b is the first directly imaged planet on a wide orbit around a G-type main-sequence star with a mass similar to that of our Sun. The planet is a gas giant, about 4 times more massive than Jupiter. It was discovered by the SEEDS survey.
planet.imagedescription:
This is an actual image of the exoplanet Gliese 504 b and its host star. It was taken by the SEEDS survey.
Credit: Kuzuhara et al. (2013).

planet.name: LKCA 15 b
planet.description: The young (2 Myr) solar analog LkCa 15 shows evidence for a (proto)planet surrounded by dusty material. The object is located in a known gap in the transitional disk. More planets might be present in this system.

planet.name: HD 10180 b
planet.description: HD 10180 is a solar type star in the constellation Hydrus. The planetary system contains at least 7 planets with masses comparable to the ice giants in the solar system. There is even evidence for two more planets, but these are still awaiting confirmation. The planets in this system are in near resonance. The age of the star is 7.3 Gigayears. The planets have been discovered with the HARPS spectrograph at the La Silla Observatory in Chile.

2MASS 04503856+0153381 b
planet.description: This hot Jupiter has been discovered by the WASP transit survey and confirmed by radial velocity measurements. It is one of the most irradiated planets known. The host star is evolved and has a post main sequence radius.

planet.name: PSR J1719-1438 b
PSR 1719-14 b
planet.description: The 5.7ms pulsar PSR J1719-14 shows timing variations on a 2.17 hour timescale. These can be explained with a Jovian planet. However, because of the planet's short distance to the star, its density has to be more then 20 times that of Jupiter. The planet is most likely a remnant of a binary star which avoided complete destruction. The chemical composition, pressure and dimensions of the planet indicate that it is crystallized, or in other words, a very big diamond (Bailes et al 2011).

planet.name: KOI-94 b
KOI-94.04

An artist's conception of the planet around HD 16141.

planet.name: KOI-206 b
planet.description: This planet was discovered with the Kepler telescope and confirmed with the SOPHIE spectrograph in France.

planet.name: WASP-72 b
1SWASPJ024409.60-301008.5 b
planet.description: Despite its extreme irradiation, this planet has a size consistant with that of Jupiter. That makes it a possible outlier among the Hot Jupiters of similar masses, suggesting a significant enrichment in heavy elements.

planet.name: CHXR 73 b
planet.description: The companion CHXR 73 b is just under the threshold for deuterium fusion. Therefor, its status as a planet is uncertain.
planet.imagedescription: This image shows the red dwarf CHXR 73 A and its companion CHXR 73 b on the lower right. The image was obtained with the Hubble Space Telescope. Credit: NASA, ESA, and K. Luhman (Pennsylvania State University).

planet.name: HD 89744 A b
HR 4067 A b
GJ 9326 A b
planet.description: This planet was discovered in 2000 by Korzennik and collaborators in 2004 Mugrauer and colleagues found a low mass stellar companion

planet.name: HD 158038 b
planet.description: The star HD 158038 hosts a Jupiter-like planet. It was discovered as part of a Doppler survey at the Keck Observatory.

planet.name: HD 215152 c
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 189733 A b
HD 189733 b
V452 Vulpeculae A b
planet.description: The planet HD 189733 b is a transiting hot Jupiter on a 2 day orbit. Astronomers have observed the secondary eclipse with the Hubble Space Telescope. They found evidence for optically thick reflective clouds on the dayside hemisphere. According to the best-fit albedo values, the planet would appear deep blue at visible wavelengths.
planet.imagedescription:
This illustration shows HD 189733b, a huge gas giant that orbits very close to its host star HD 189733. The planet's atmosphere is scorching with a temperature of over 1000 degrees Celsius, and it rains glass, sideways, in howling 7000 kilometre-per-hour winds.
At a distance of 63 light-years from us, this turbulent alien world is one of the nearest exoplanets to Earth that can be seen crossing the face of its star. By observing this planet before, during, and after it disappeared behind its host star during orbit, astronomers were able to deduce that HD 189733b is a deep, azure blue - reminiscent of Earth's colour as seen from space.
Credit: NASA, ESA, M. Kornmesser

planet.name: HAT-P-37 b
2MASS 18571105+5116088
planet.description: HAT-P-37 b is a transiting planet that has been discovered by the HATNet collaboration. HATNet is a ground-based survey using standard telephoto lenses such as the Canon 11cm diameter f/1.8L.

planet.description: The star BD-103166 is a K-type main sequence star in the constellation Crater. It is three times as metal-rich as our Sun.

KOI-2672.01

planet.description: 42 Draconis is a metal poor star.

planet.name: Gliese 86 b
GJ 86 b
Gj 86 b
Gl 86 b
planet.description: The star Gliese 86 is a K-type dwarf star and a member of a binary system in the constellation Eridanus. A linear trend in the radial velocity data may be associated with the stellar companion or another planetary companion.

planet.name: RR Cae (AB) b
planet.description: The binary RR Cae contains a cool white dwarf and an M-Type dwarf. Eclipse timing variations were used to find a circumbinary planet on an orbit nearly identical to that of Jupiter.

planet.name: HIP 63242 b
planet.description: The planet HIP 63242 b is the innermost planet detected around any intermediate-mass giant star. The lack of other close-in planets suggests that these planets might be destroyed by the large envelope of the host star during the red giant phase.

planet.name: HD 132563B b
planet.description: HD 132563B b is a planet in a triple star system. It is orbiting the solar type star HD 132563B which has a solar type companion HD 132563A orbiting at 400 AU. HD 132563A itself is yet another spectroscopic binary.

planet.name: WASP-97 b
1SWASP J013825.04-554619.4 b
2MASS 01382504-5546194 b
planet.description: This is a hot Jupiter discovered by the WASP team.

planet.name: HD 106270 b
planet.description: The star HD 106270 hosts a Jupiter-like planet. It was discovered as part of a Doppler survey at the Keck Observatory.

planet.name: Kepler-69 b
KOI-172 b
planet.description: Kepler-69 is a two planet system which was discovered by Kepler. Kepler-69 b is a planet in a 14 day orbit and too hot to sustain liquid water on the surface. However, the outer planet, Kepler-69 c, might be in the habitable zone.

planet.name: Kepler-69 c
KOI-172 c
planet.description: Kepler-69 is a two planet system discovered by Kepler. Kepler-69 c, the outer planet, is orbiting the star every 242 days and might be in the habitable zone. It is 70 percent larger than Earth. Not much is known about its composition.
planet.imagedescription:
Artist's concept of planet Kepler-69c, a super-Earth-size planet (70% larger than Earth). It is the smallest yet found orbiting in the habitable zone of a sun-like star. Its orbit of 242 days resembles that of our neighboring planet Venus.
Credit: NASA/Ames/JPL-Caltech.

HD 4732 b

KIC 8359498 b
GSC2.3 N2K0000444
USNO-A2 1275-11111739 b
2MASS 19182590+4420435 b
planet.description: KOI-127 b is a transiting Saturn-mass planet in a 3.6 day orbit. It was found in the publicly available Kepler photometry from quarters 1-13 and has been confirmed independently with ground based spectroscopy. The planet has one of the lowest albedos of all known gas giants (less than 0.087).

planet.name: HD 209458 b
planet.description: By studying the carbon monoxide gas in the upper atmosphere with great accuracy, astronomers found evidence for a wind, blowing at a speed of 5000 to 10000 km per hour.
planet.imagedescription:
Astronomers have measured a superstorm for the first time in the atmosphere of the planet HD 209458 b. The very high-precision observations of carbon monoxide gas show that it is streaming at enormous speed from the extremely hot day side to the cooler night side of the planet.
This artist's impression shows the Jupiter-like transiting planet around its solar-like host star.
Credit:
ESO/L. Calcada

planet.name: KOI-961 b
KOI-961.01
planet.description: KOI-961 is an M-dwarf with transit signals of at least three short-period planets. The properties of the star are very similar to those of Barnard's star, the fourth closest star to the Sun. All planets in the system are very close to their host star and thought to be rocky. The system is more similar in size to Jupiter and its moons than any other planetary system.
planet.imagedescription:
Artist's concept of the planetary system KOI-961 with three planets orbiting an M-dwarf.
Image credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech

LHS 188 c
planet.description: The HARPS team announced the discovery of a planetary system around the star Gliese 163 at this year's IAU conference. Gliese 163 c lies within the habitable zone for a wide range of albedo values and has an equilibrium temperature of 60C (140F).

planet.name: POTS-1 b
2MASS 13342613-6634520 b
planet.description: POTS-1 b is a Hot Jupiter and the first planet discovered by the pre-OmegaTranS project survey. This survey is looking at the Carina region of the Galactic disc with the European Southern Observatory Wide Field Imager at La Silla Observatory.

planet.name: HD 137388 b
planet.description: HD 137388 b was found with the European High Accuracy Radial velocity Planet Searcher (HARPS) which can reach sub-meter-per-second precision. The planet orbits a K type star.

planet.name: BD20 2457 b
planet.description: The star BD+242457 is located in the constellation Leo. Its metallicity is ten times lower compared to our Sun.yy

planet.name: HD 95086 b
HIP 53524 b
2MASS J10570301-6840023 b
TYC 9212-4675-1 b
planet.description: HD 95086 b is a planet that has been directly imaged with ESO's Very Large Telescope. The mass, determined by evolutionary models, is 5 Jupitermasses, making it the lowest mass planet detected by direct imaging. The planet is very bright (and therefore detectable) because the system is only 17 million years old. The Solar System, as a comparison, is over 4 billion years old.
planet.imagedescription:
This image from ESO's Very Large Telescope (VLT) shows the newly discovered planet HD95086 b, next to its parent star. The observations were made using NACO, the adaptative optics instrument for the VLT in infrared light, and using a technique called differential imaging, which improves the contrast between the planet and its dazzling host star. The star itself has been removed from the picture during processing to enhance the view of the faint exoplanet and its position is marked. The exoplanet appears at the lower left.
The blue circle is the size of the orbit of Neptune in the Solar System.
The star HD 95086 has similar properties to Beta Pictoris and HR 8799 around which giant planets have previously been imaged at separations between 8 and 68 astronomical units. These stars are all young, more massive than the Sun, and surrounded by a debris disc.
Credit: ESO/J. Rameau

planet.description: This is a Kepler Object of Interest from the Q1-Q12 dataset. It has been flagged as a possible transit event but has not been confirmed to be a planet yet.

planet.name: OGLE-2012-BLG-0406L b
planet.description: This planetary system was discovered during a high-magnification gravitational microlensing event. It is the first microlensing planet found by analyzing data from only a single telescope. The planet is located beyond the snow-line. Some core accretion theories favor the formation of massive planets inside the snow-line. However, planetary migration in the protoplanetary disk might explain why the planet has moved outwards.

planet.name: HD 220773 b
planet.description: The Jovian planet HD 220773b is orbiting an F9-type star. It has a predicted displacement of 0.242mas and might be an interesting target for astrometry.

planet.name: 16 Cygni B b
16 Cyg B b
HD 186427 B b
planet.description: 16 Cygni is a hierarchical triple system. The star is in the Kepler field of view. In an active search for extra-terrestrial intelligence a radio message has been sent to this system on May 24 1999. It will reach the system in 2069.

planet.name: HD 2952 b
HR 135 b
planet.description: The planet HD 2952 b is orbiting an evolved intermediate-mass star. The radial velocity measurements were taken at the Okaya Astrophysical Observatory.

CoRoTID 102890318 b
planet.description: The star CoRoT-1 is a sun-like star in the constellation of Monoceros. The planet CoRoT-1b is the first planet discovered by the European space mission CoRoT (COnvection, ROtation and planetary Tansits).

planet.name: KOI-368 b
KOI-368.01
KOI-0368 b
KOI-0368 01
planet.description: The planet KOI-368 b was flagged by the Kepler team as a planet candidate. A new study by Zhou and Huang has now excluded blend scenarios and argues that the object has to be of substellar nature. The planet has a very high obliquity of 64 degrees. KOI-368 is the hottest host star to date for systems with spin-orbit measurements.

planet.name: HD 11506 b
planet.description: The star HD 11506 is a yellow dwarf star in the constellation Cetus. The star hosts two planets. The inner planer was discovered by using Bayesian analysis (Tuomi et al 2009).

KOI-196 b
2MASS J19380317+4558539 b
planet.description: KOI-196 b, also known as Kepler-41 b, is transiting its host star and was tagged as a planet candidate by the Kepler spacecraft. Astronomers then used the SOPHIE spectrograph at the Observatoire de Haute-Provence in France to confirm the planet. The day side temperature on the planet is almost 1700 degree Celsius. In 2013, it was independently confirmed by a phase curve analysis.

planet.name: Kepler-31 b
KOI 935.01
KIC 9347899 b
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. Because there are multiple phenomena that can create a signal that looks similar to a planetary transit, the candidates have to be confirmed with another method. For Kepler-31 the planetary nature of the companions has been confirmed by transit timing variations, caused by other planets in the system, and a stability analysis. However, the mass of the planets is not well constrained yet. There are at least two other unconfirmed planets in the system.

planet.name: Kepler-31 c
KOI 935.02

Because there are multiple phenomena that can create a signal that looks similar to a planetary transit, the candidates have to be confirmed with another method. For Kepler-31 the planetary nature of the companions has been confirmed by transit timing variations, caused by other planets in the system, and a stability analysis. However, the mass of the planets is not well constrained yet and is just an upper limit. There are at least two other unconfirmed planets in the system.

KOI-870.01

Because there are multiple phenomena that can create a signal that looks similar to a planetary transit, the candidates have to be confirmed with another method. For Kepler-28 the planetary nature of the companions has been confirmed by transit timing variations, caused by other planets in the system, and a stability analysis. However, the mass of the planets is not well constrained yet.

planet.name: HD 99706 b
planet.description: The star HD 99706 hosts a Jupiter-like planet. It was discovered as part of a Doppler survey at the Keck Observatory.

2MASS J20124017-0208391 b
TYC 7038-834-1 b
BPM 80815 b
GSC 05165-00481 b
planet.description: WASP-80 b is a Jupiter-sized exoplanet but it has only half of Jupiter's mass. It has a transit depth of 3 percent, one of the largest reported so far.

planet.name: HIP 91258 b
planet.description: HIP 91258 is a Hot Jupiter with an orbital period of only 5 days. There is another planet in the system. However, currently only a quadratic trend is seen in the data which is insufficient to determine the second planet's properties. The planet was discovered with the SOPHIE spectrograph in France.

planet.name: HD 128311 b
planet.description: This planetary system is most likely in a 2:1 mean motion resonance. The inner planet orbits the star exactly twice during one orbit of the outer planet. This is a very stable configuration. Mean motion resonances help us to understand the formation of multiplanteray systems. The existense of this resonance is a strong indication that interactions with the protoplanetary disk migrated the planets to their current positions. A detailed analysis of the HD 128311 system shows that there also had to be non-adiabatic effects during the migration phase such as a third planet (Sandor and Kley 2006) or turbulence in the protoplanetary disk (Rein and Papaloizou 2009).

WASP-2 b
2MASS J20305413+0625463 b

KIC 10264660 b

2MASS J19105011+4719589 b

2MASS J04252901-3036016 b
TYC 7038-834-1 b

GSC 7038-834 b

planet.name: HD 41248 b
planet.description: The planetary system HD 41248 consists of at least two planets. Both planets are most likely Super-Earths. Their period ratio is close to the integer ratio 7:5, a second order commensurability.

planet.name: HD 41248 c
planet.description: The planetary system HD 41248 consists of at least two planets. Both planets are most likely Super-Earths. Their period ratio is close to the integer ratio 7:5, a second order commensurability.

planet.name: HD 75289 A b
planet.description: The Sun-like star HD 75289 is located in the constellation Velo. It is part of a binary system. The companion is a red dwarf. It also hosts a gas giant which was detected by Udry et al. in 1999.

planet.name: KOI-202 b
planet.description: This planet was discovered with the Kepler telescope and confirmed with the SOPHIE spectrograph in France.

planet.name: AB Pic b
planet.description: AB Pictoris is a star in the constellation of Pictor. Because of its high mass, the companion could be a planet or a brown dwarf.
planet.imagedescription: This is a coronagraphic image of AB Pictoris. A planetary companion is visible on the lower left. It was optained with NACO on the VLT with an occulting mask on top of AB Pictoris. Credit: ESO.

BD+01 316 b
1SWASP J014631.86+024202.0 b
2MASS 01463185+0242019 b

KOI-1563.01
KIC 5219234 b

2MASS J19533486+4748540 b
KOI-203 b
KIC 10619192 b
planet.description: Kepler-17b is a planet on a short orbit around a solar mass star. One year on this planet equals 1.5 days on Earth. Star spots on the host star constrain the eccentricity and obliquity of the planet.

planet.name: Kepler-16 (AB) b
planet.description: Kepler-16 (AB) b is a circum-binary planet. It is orbiting two stars. The orbit of the binary stars and the planet are perfectly alligned within half a degree. This suggests that the planet formed in a circumbinary disc.
planet.imagedescription: This image shows an artist's illustration of the Kepler-16 (AB) b exo-planet orbiting two binary stars. Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/R. Hurt

planet.name: HD 77338 b
planet.description: The planet HD77338 b is a Hot Uranus orbiting a super metal-rich K0V star. It was discovered by the Calan-Hertfordshire Extrasolar Planet Search.

planet.name: DP Leo b
planet.description: DP Leonis is an eclipsing binary system.

planet.name: WASP-70A b
planet.description: WASP-70A b is part of a binary system. The planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team. It was published in a paper in October 2013.

planet.name: HIP 11952 b
planet.description: This planet was announced in 2012. But a new study in 2013 using the HARPS-N spectrograph did not find any evidence for giant planets in the system. The planet is therefore labeled as constroversial.

planet.name: HIP 11952 c
planet.description: This planet was announced in 2012. But a new study in 2013 using the HARPS-N spectrograph did not find any evidence for giant planets in the system. The planet is therefore labeled as constroversial.

planet.name: CT Cha b
planet.description: CT Chamaeleontis is a pre-main sequence T Tauri star. The companion might be a brown dwarf due to its large mass.
planet.imagedescription: This image shows the young star CT Cha and a companion (on the right). Due to its large mass it is currently unclear if the companion is a planet or brown dwarf. Credit: Tobias Schmidt (AIU Jena).

planet.name: Kepler-10 c
KIC 11904151 c
2MASS J19024305+5014286 c
planet.description: This planet was confirmed using infrared observations from Spitzer. It is highly unlikely (0.002%) that Kepler-10 c is a false positive. The planet is so close to its host star that it can not sustain liquid water on its surface. It is therefore most likely not habitable and a scorched, molten Earth.

planet.name: WASP-95 b

2MASS 22294972-4800111 b

HR 4934 b
planet.description: The planet HD 113337 b is orbiting a bright young F-type star. An IR excess has been attributed to a cold debris disk around the star. The planet has been found with the SOPHIE spectrograph on the 1.9m telescope at Observatoire de Haute-Provence.

planet.name: HD 13908 b
planet.description: HD 13908 b is a Hot Jupiter with an orbital period of 19 days. There is another planet in the system with a perdio of over 900 days. The system was discovered with the SOPHIE spectrograph in France.

planet.name: HD 13908 c
planet.description: HD 13908 c is a planet with 5 times the mass of our Jupiter. The system HD 13908 also hosts a hot Jupiter with an orbital period of 19 days. The system was discovered with the SOPHIE spectrograph in France.

planet.name: HD 38529 A b
138 G. Orionis A b
planet.description: The star system HD 38529 contains a yellow subgiant (the planet hosting star) and a red dwarf. The binary separation is 12000 astronomical units. A debris disc has been detected around the planet hosting star beyond 86 astronomical units.

planet.name: HD 38529 A c
planet.description: The star system HD 38529 contains a yellow subgiant (the planet hosting star) and a red dwarf. The binary separation is 12000 astronomical units. A debris disc has been detected around the planet hosting star beyond 86 astronomical units.

planet.name: Kepler-62 b
KIC-9002278 b
KOI-701 b
planet.description: The Kepler-62 system has five planets. Two of them orbit in the habitable zone. Only the size, not the mass of planets in this system is known. Kepler-62 could be the Holy Grail of exoplanetology: a system with a rocky or water planet in the habitable zone.

planet.description: The star system HD 147513, also known as HR 6094, consists of a Sun-like star, a white dwarf stellar remnant and a Jupiter-mass planet. The planet was discovered on 18 June 2002.

planet.name: WASP-46 b
2MASS J21145687-5552184 b
planet.description: WASP-46 b has about twice the mass of Jupiter and orbits a G6V star which shows evidence of being photospherically and chromospherically active.

planet.name: WASP-12 b
WASP-12 A b
2MASS J06303279+2940202 b
planet.description: The host star of WASP-12 b is the primary of a hierarchical triple system. The distant binary consists of two M dwarfs.

planet.name: UScoCTIO 108 b
planet.imagedescription: This composite color image shows UScoCTIO 108 together with its companion. Credit: V.J.S. Bejar, Telescopio Nazionale Galileo, William Herschel Telescope.

planet.name: 2M1207 b
2MASS J12073346-3932539 b
planet.description: 2M1207 might be the first directly imaged extrasolar planet. However, due to its high mass it might also classify as a brown dwarf.
planet.imagedescription: This image shows the brown dwarf 2M1207 and a planetary companion (lower left). It was the first image of an extrasolar planet and has been published 2004. Credit: ESO.

planet.name: KOI-423 b
KIC 9478990 b
planet.description: This planet was confirmed by SOPHIE measurements (Bouchy et al. 2011).

planet.name: 91 Aquarii A b
91 Aqr A b
HD 219449 A b
HIP 114855 A b
Gliese 893.2 A b
planet.description: 91 Aquarii is a triple star system in the constellation Aquarius. It is visible to the naked eye and is host to at least one extrasolar planet.

planet.name: MOA-2012-BLG-311 b
planet.description: This object was observed in a gravitational mirolensing event. A good mass estimate could not be obtained although the object is most likely of planetary nature. Unfortunately microlensing events are not repeatable and the planet is therefore marked as controversial.

HIP 80076 b
TYC 3065-01195-1 b
HD 147506 b
BD+41 2693 b

2MASS J16203635+4102531 b
planet.description: The star HAT-P-2 is located in the constellation Hercules and is between 2 and 3 billion years old.

planet.name: KOI-274 b
KOI-274 1
planet.description: This planet was discovered by the Kepler spacecraft. The planet is part of a multiplanetary system. Its planetary nature has been confirmed using transit timing variations which arise because the planets in one system pull on each other and slightly alter the transit times.

planet.name: KOI-274 c
KOI-274 2
planet.description: This planet was discovered by the Kepler spacecraft. The planet is part of a multiplanetary system. Its planetary nature has been confirmed using transit timing variations which arise because the planets in one system pull on each other and slightly alter the transit times.

TYC 2652-01324-1
2MASS J19040985+3637574
planet.description: TrES-1 b orbits an orange dwarf star in the constellation of Lyra. It belongs to the class of Hot Jupiters

planet.name: NSVS 14256825 c
planet.description: NSVS 14256825 is an HW Vir type binary which consists of a hot subdwarf and a main-sequence low-mass star in a close orbit.

planet.name: NSVS 14256825 d
planet.description: NSVS 14256825 is an HW Vir type binary which consists of a hot subdwarf and a main-sequence low-mass star in a close orbit.

planet.name: HD 19994 A b
94 Ceti A b
Gliese 128 A b
GJ 128 A b
planet.description: The star system 94 Ceti (also known ad HD 19994) is an eccentric binary approximately 73 light years away from Earth. A planet orbiting the primary star was discovered in 2000 by the European Southern Observatory.

planet.name: KOI-13 b
KOI-13.01
planet.description: The exoplanet candidate KOI-13 b was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. It has been independently confirmed by ellipsoidal variations in the lightcurve. The high temperature of the host star and the small semi-major axis make this planet one of the hottest exoplanets known. The equilibrium temperature is 2864K.

planet.name: Kepler-49 b
KOI 248.01
KID 5364071
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered by the Kepler spacecraft. It transits its host star every 7.20 days for 2.9766 hours. Periodic transit timing variations confirm its planetary nature.

planet.name: Kepler-49 c
KOI 248.02
KID 5364071
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered by the Kepler spacecraft. It transits its host star every 10.91 days for 2.8577 hours. Periodic transit timing variations confirm its planetary nature.

planet.name: HD 7449 b
planet.description: HD 7449 b was found with the European High Accuracy Radial velocity Planet Searcher (HARPS) which can reach sub-meter-per-second precision. The planetary system contains at least one other planet, HD 7449 c. The host star shows signs of short-term activity due to magnetic features on the stellar surface.

planet.name: HD 7449 c
planet.description: HD 7449 c was found with the European High Accuracy Radial velocity Planet Searcher (HARPS) which can reach sub-meter-per-second precision. The planetary system contains at least one other planet, HD 7449 b. The host star shows signs of short-term activity due to magnetic features on the stellar surface.

planet.name: HD 116029 b
planet.description: The star HD 116029 hosts a Jupiter-like planet. It was discovered as part of a Doppler survey at the Keck Observatory.

planet.name: HD 195019 A b
planet.description: The planet is orbiting a star that is part of a binary system. The planet's periastron is far enough away from the host star such that tides are not important.

planet.name: WASP-62 b
planet.description: This planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team.

planet.name: HD 177830 A b
planet.description: The star HD 177830 A hosts at least two planets. The planets are close to the 4:1 resonance. The star is four times brighter than our Sun but only visible with binoculars from the Earth.

planet.name: HD 177830 A c
planet.description: The star HD 177830 A hosts at least two planets. The planets are close to the 4:1 resonance. The star is four times brighter than our Sun but only visible with binoculars from the Earth.

planet.name: Alpha Centauri B b
GJ 559 B b
HR 5460 b
HD 128621 b
HIP 71681 b
Albertus Alauda
planet.description: Alpha Centauri is one of the brightest stars in the southern sky (in fact, it is a triple system). European astronomers have discovered a planet with about the mass of the Earth orbiting Alpha Centauri B. It is the nearest exoplanet to Earth and also the lightest exoplanet ever discovered around a Sun-like star. The planet was detected using the HARPS instrument on the 3.6-metre telescope at ESO's La Silla Observatory in Chile.
planet.imagedescription:
This artist's impression shows the planet orbiting the star Alpha Centauri B, a member of the triple star system that is the closest to Earth. Alpha Centauri B is the most brilliant object in the sky and the other dazzling object is Alpha Centauri A. Our own Sun is visible to the upper right. The tiny signal of the planet was found with the HARPS spectrograph on the 3.6-metre telescope at ESO's La Silla Observatory in Chile.
Credit: ESO/L. Calcada

planet.name: PSO J318.5-22
PSO J318.5338-22.8603
2MASS J21140802-2251358
WISE J211408.13-225137.3
PSO J318-22
planet.description: PSO J318-22 is a free floating planetary mass object. It was discovered using the Pan-STARRS1 survey and is part of the beta Pictoris moving group. Evolutionary models give the object a temperature of 1160K and a mass about 6 times that of Jupiter, making PSO J318-22 one of the lowest mass free-floating objects in the solar neighborhood.

planet.name: HD 134606 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 134606 c
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 134606 d
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 178911 B b
planet.description: The planet HD 178911 B b is part of a stellar triple system. The wide binary separation is approximately 640 astronomical units. The planet was found using the HIRES and ELODIE spectrographs mounted on telescopes in Hawaii and France.

planet.name: Kepler-27 b
KOI 841.01
KIC 5792202 b
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. Its host star gets periodically fainter whenever the planet is in front of the star. Because there are multiple phenomena that can create a signal that looks similar to a planetary transit, the candidates have to be confirmed with another method. For Kepler-27 the planetary nature of the companions has been confirmed by transit timing variations, caused by other planets in the system, and a stability analysis. However, the mass of the planets is not well constrained yet.

planet.name: Kepler-27 c
KOI 841.02
KIC 5792202 c

Because there are multiple phenomena that can create a signal that looks similar to a planetary transit, the candidates have to be confirmed with another method. For Kepler-27 the planetary nature of the companions has been confirmed by transit timing variations, caused by other planets in the system, and a stability analysis. However, the mass of the planets is not well constrained yet.

planet.name: tau Boo A b
Tau Booetis A b
HD 120136 A b
GJ 527 A b
Gliese 527 A b
planet.description: The planet Tau Bootis b was one of the first exoplanets to be discovered back in 1996. In 2012, astronomers have detected the faint glow that is emitted from the planet, reliably probing the structure of the atmosphere of Tau Bootis b and deducing its mass accurately for the first time.
planet.imagedescription:
This artist's impression shows the exoplanet Tau Bootis b.
Credit: ESO/L. Calcada

planet.name: Gliese 221 b
GJ 221 b
BD-061339 b
HIP 27803 b
planet.description: The planets orbiting the K7 star GJ 221 were discovered using publicly available HARPS data. The dataset was complemented with high precision Doppler measurements from Magellan/PFS. The system hosts at least two planets, one hot Super-Earth and one sub-Saturn mass planet.

GJ 221 c

planet.name: WASP-57 b
planet.description: This planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team.

planet.name: BD-17 63 b
planet.description: The star BD-1763 is a K-type star in the constellation Cetus. It is five times less luminous than our Sun.

planet.name: HD 220074 b
planet.description: The observation of this planet was made using the fiber-fed Bohyunsan Observatory Echelle Spectrograph between September 2008 to June 2012.

planet.name: HD 197037 b
planet.description: This planet was found by looking at 113 radial velocity data points which have been obtained over the last 10 years with a 2.7m telescope.

planet.name: WASP-101 b
1SWASP J063324.26-232910.2 b
2MASS 06332426-2329103 b
planet.description: This is a hot Jupiter discovered by the WASP team.

planet.name: Pr0201 b
BD+20 2184
2MASS J08414382+2013368
planet.description: This planet is a so-called Hot Jupiter which orbits tightly around its parent star in the Beehive Cluster, a collection of roughly 1,000 stars that appear to be swarming around a common center. The planet is not habitable but its sky would be starrier than what we see from Earth.
planet.imagedescription:
Artist's impression of a planet in the Beehive cluster.
Image credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech

planet.name: HD 100655 b
planet.description: HD 100655b is a planetary companion to a star which is more than twice as massive as our Sun. Even though the planet is heavier than Jupiter, it is the lowest-mass planet known around giant stars with more than 1.9 solar masses.

planet.name: NY Virginis (AB) b
NY Vir (AB) b
PG 1336-018 (AB) b
planet.description: The rapidly pulsating eclipsing binary NY Virginis has a period of 0.1 days. On a much longer timescale of 7.9 years, the system exhibits small amplitude cyclic variations which are associated with a third body in the system. A recent paper by Qian et. al. claims that this body is a giant circumbinary planet orbiting NY Vir at a distance of 3.3 astronomical units. There might be another planet in this system with an even longer orbital period, probably more than 15 years.

planet.name: BD+30 1138 b
TYC 2996-683-1 b
2MASS J09543439+4023170 b
GSC 02996-00683 b
SAO 43097 b
planet.description: KELT-3 b is a moderately inflated transiting hot Jupiter. It is orbiting a late F-type start which is among the 20 brightest known transiting planet host stars. It was discovered by the Kilodegree Extremely Little Telescope-North (KELT-North) survey.
planet.name: KELT-3 b
KOI-142 b
planet.description: The planets in the KOI-142 have been confirmed using transit timing (TTV) and transit duration variations (TDV). The planets are just wide of the 2:1 mean motion resonance. It is often assumed that convergent migration locks planets in resonances. Then, multiple effects such as stochastic migration can move the planets slightly out of resonance. This is an important clue that might help scientists understand the formation of planetary systems. Note that the mass of the inner planet KOI-142 b is an upper limit.

planet.name: KOI-142 c
planet.description: The planets in the KOI-142 have been confirmed using transit timing (TTV) and transit duration variations (TDV). The planets are just wide of the 2:1 mean motion resonance. It is often assumed that convergent migration locks planets in resonances. Then, multiple effects such as stochastic migration can move the planets slightly out of resonance. This is an important clue that might help scientists understand the formation of planetary systems.

planet.name: HD 96127 b
planet.description: This planet was found by the Penn State-Torun Planet Search Team (PTPS) using the Hobby-Eberly Telescope. The host star is a K2 giant.

planet.name: CoRoT-7 b
CoRoT-Exo-7 b
CoRoTID 102708694 b
planet.description: CoRoT 7 is a G-type star in the constellation Monoceros. The planet CoRoR 7b was the first rocky planet found. However, due to its high temperature the planet might be covered in lava.

planet.name: CoRoT-7 c
CoRoT-Exo-7 c
CoRoTID 102708694 c
planet.description: The star CoRoT 7c is a G-type star in the constellation Monoceros. The planet is not transiting.

planet.name: MOA-2011-BLG-322 b
HJD 2455773 b
planet.description: MOA-2011-BLG-322 b is a giant planet which was discovered by MOA, OGLE and the Wise Observatory. These observatories form a network and conduct a second generation microlensing survey. The survey aims to discover and characterize extrasolar planets and their frequency, by means of round-the-clock high-cadence monitoring of a large area of the Galactic bulge.

planet.name: KOI-2038 b
KOI-2038.01
KIC 8950568 b
planet.description: The system KOI-2038 was discovered using transit data from the Kepler telescope. The planetary nature of the system was confirmed using transit timing variations.

planet.description: The system KOI-2038 was discovered using transit data from the Kepler telescope. The planetary nature of the system was confirmed using transit timing variations.

MOA-192 b
planet.description: The exoplanet MOA-2007-BLG-192-L b is orbiting a low mass brown dwarf, roughly 6% the mass of our Sun. This makes the primary too small to sustain fusion.

Artist's impression of the extrasolar planet MOA-2007-BLG-192-L b.

planet.name: KOI-680 b
planet.description: This planet was discovered with the Kepler telescope and confirmed with the SOPHIE spectrograph in France.

planet.name: 1RXS1609 b
planet.description: 1RXS J160929.1-210524 is a 5 million year old pre-main sequence star in the constellation of Scorpius. The observed planet has a large semi-major axis, posing problems for current formation scenarios. Two possibilities are that the planet formed by gravitational instability or migrated outwards.
planet.imagedescription: This image of the host star and the planet was taken with the Gemini North telescope and released in September 2008. Credit: Gemini Observatory.

planet.name: 55 Cnc b
planet.description: 55 Cancri is a binary system in the constellation Cancer. 55 Cnc b and c are in a near 1:3 resonance. A dynamical analysis shows that the system has to be almost coplanar in order to be stable for the age the system.

2MASS 08130018+0447132

TYC 3416-00543-1 b
2MASS J08393180+4721073 b

TYC 3416-00543-1 c
2MASS J08393180+4721073 c

planet.name: HD 114729 A b
planet.description: The planet HD 114720 A b is orbiting a Sun-like star approximately 114 light years away. It has a mass similar to Jupiter and was discovered by the California and Carnegie Planet Search.

planet.name: Kepler-66 b
planet.description: Kepler-66 b is orbiting a Sun-like star in the billion-year-old open cluster NGC6811. It demonstrates that small planets can form and survive in a dense cluster environment. The frequency of planets around stars in open cluster and field stars in the Milky Way are approximately the same.

planet.name: HR 8799 b
planet.description: The star HR 8799 is a young star in the constellation of Pegasus. It hosts a debris disk and at least 3 planets. The objects are near the upper limit for being planets. Objects are classified as brown dwarfs if they are capable of deuterium fusion (above 13 Jupiter masses).
planet.imagedescription: This image shows three planets orbiting the star HR 8799. It was obtained with the Keck II telescope on Hawaii. Credit: C. Marois et al., NRC Canada.

HD 46375 b
planet.description: This star is on its way to becoming a red giant. It is considerably older than the sun. It has a stellar companion at a distance of 345 astronomical units.

planet.name: 6 Lyn b
planet.description: The star 6 Lyncis is a subgiant and 15 times more luminous than our Sun.

KOI 262.01
KID 11807274
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered by the Kepler spacecraft. It transits its host star every 7.81 days for 4.2439 hours. Periodic transit timing variations confirm its planetary nature.

KOI 262.02
KID 11807274
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered by the Kepler spacecraft. It transits its host star every 9.38 days for 2.6022 hours. Periodic transit timing variations confirm its planetary nature.

planet.name: HD 159243 b
planet.description: The HD 159243 system contains two planets, one of which (HD 159243 b) is a hot Jupiter with an orbital period of 12.6 days. The system was discovered with the SOPHIE spectrograph in France.

planet.name: HD 159243 c
planet.description: The HD 159243 system contains two planets, one of which (HD 159243 b) is a hot Jupiter with an orbital period of 12.6 days. The system was discovered with the SOPHIE spectrograph in France.

planet.name: MOA-2011-BLG-293L b
planet.description: MOA-2011-BLG-293L b is a planet discovered by gravitational microlensing. Using follow-up observations on Keck, astronomers have identified the planet to lie in or near the habitable zone. It could in principle have habitable moons. It is also the first planet to be identified as being in the Galactic bulge with good confidence.

planet.name: KELT-2A b
HIP 29301 b
WDS J06107+3057A b
TYC 2420-00899-1 b
HD 42176 b
BD+30 1138 b
SAO 58830 b
2MASS J06103935+3057258 b
planet.description: This planet is a typical Hot Jupiter. It is the first planet discovered by the Kilodegree Extremely Little Telescope-North (KELT-North) survey. KELT-2A is the third brightest star with a transiting planet identified by ground-based transit surveys, and the ninth brightest star overall with a transiting planet. The planet might have been put on its orbit by the binary companion KELT-2B via the so-called eccentric Kozai mechanism.

planet.name: KOI-730 b
planet.description: The planetary system KOI-730 has been discovered by Kepler. The planet masses have not been confirmed. However, a dynamical study by Fabrycky et al suggests that this system is real.

LP 424-4

planet.description: The planet Gliese 3470 b is a transiting Hot Uranus orbiting a nearby M-dwarf. The planet was originally seen in HARPS radial velocity data and then confirmed to be a transiting planet. Spitzer observations show that it has a very low density.

planet.name: HAT-P-41 b
2MASS 19491743+0440207
planet.description: HAT-P-41 b is a highly inflated hot Jupiter. The planet is less massive than Jupiter but has a much larger radius. It has been discovered by the HATNet collaboration.

planet.name: HD 164509 b
planet.description: HD 164509 is a metal rich G5V star with at least one planet. A linear trend in the RV residuals suggest the existance of an additional planet.

WASP-51 b
WASP-51

planet.description: This exoplanet is transiting the dwarf star GSC 0208-00722. The sky projection of the planet's orbit normal and the star's spin axis is 73.5 degrees.

planet.name: HD 30856 b
planet.description: The star HD 30856 hosts a Jupiter-like planet. It was discovered as part of a Doppler survey at the Keck Observatory.

planet.name: HD 82886 b
planet.description: The star HD 82886 hosts a Jupiter-like planet. It was discovered as part of a Doppler survey at the Keck Observatory.

GJ 674 b
Gj 674 b
Gl 674 b
planet.description: Gliese 674 is a pre main sequence star in the constellation of Ara.

CoRoT-Exo-9 b
2MASS J18430881+0612150 b
CoRoTID 105891283 b
planet.description: The star CoRoT 9 is located in the constellation Serpens. The density of the planet is approximately that of water.

planet.name: Gliese 317 b
GJ 317 b
Gj 317 b
Gl 317 b
planet.description: The star Gliese 317 is a red dwarf in the constellation Pyxis. So far only one planet is confirmed. There might be a second planet in the system, locked in a 4:1 mean motion resonance.

planet.name: HATS-3 b
2MASS 20494978-2425436 b
GSC 6926-00454 b
planet.description: HATS-3 b is a transiting exoplanet, discovered by HATSouth and confirmed with reconnaissance spectroscopy. HATSouth is a network of automated telescopes that is capable of year-round 24-hour monitoring of stars over the entire southern hemisphere of the sky. Because of the brightness of the host star, HATS-3 b is an interesting target for future observations to measure the Rossiter-McLaughlin effect and determine the spin-orbit alignment of the system.

planet.name: WASP-68 b
planet.description: This planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team.

planet.name: HAT-P-42 b
2MASS 09012265+0605500 b
planet.description: HAT-P-42 b is a typical Hot Jupiter on a circular orbit around an early G-type main sequence star. The planet is inflated compared to our own Jupiter. It was discovered by the HATNet collaboration.

planet.name: Kepler-76 b
KIC 4570949 b
Einstein's Planet
planet.description: This planet was discovered in a Kepler lightcurve using the BEER algorithm (BEaming effect with Ellipsoidal and Reflection modulations). Follow-up observations using spectra from TRES and SOPHIE confirmed the planetary nature of the object. The planet has the nickname "Einstein's Planet" because the confirmation method makes use of special relativity.

planet.name: Kepler-30 b
KOI 806.01
KIC 3832474 b
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. Because there are multiple phenomena that can create a signal that looks similar to a planetary transit, the candidates have to be confirmed with another method. For Kepler-30 the planetary nature of the companions has been confirmed by transit timing variations, caused by other planets in the system, and a stability analysis.

planet.name: Kepler-30 c
KOI 806.02
KIC 3832474 c
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. Its host star gets periodically fainter whenever the planet is in front of the star. Because there are multiple phenomena that can create a signal that looks similar to a planetary transit, the candidates have to be confirmed with another method. For Kepler-30 the planetary nature of the companions has been confirmed by transit timing variations, caused by other planets in the system, and a stability analysis.

planet.name: WASP-20 b
planet.description: This planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team.

planet.name: Fomalhaut b
Fomalhaut Ab
HD 216956 b
HR 8728 b
CD-30 19370 b
CPD-30 6685 b
SAO 191524 b
GJ 881 b
2MASS J22573901-2937193 b
HIP 113368 b
IRAS 22549-2953 b
ALF PsA b
24 PsA b
planet.description: Formalhaut is one of the brightest stars in the night sky and located in the constellation Piscis Austrinus. It is a young star with a debris disk. In 2008 astronomers reported the discovery of a planet orbiting the star within the debris disk. Images from the Hubble space telescope show motion consistent with a Keplerian orbit that crossed the disk. However, there are still debates about where the observed emission is coming from.
planet.imagedescription:
This false-color composite image, taken with the Hubble Space Telescope, reveals the orbital motion of the planet Fomalhaut b. The planet will appear to cross a vast belt of debris around the star roughly 20 years from now. If the planet's orbit lies in the same plane with the belt, icy and rocky debris in the belt could crash into the planet's atmosphere and produce various phenomena. The black circle at the center of the image blocks out the light from the bright star, allowing reflected light from the belt and planet to be photographed.
Credit: NASA, ESA, and P. Kalas (University of California, Berkeley and SETI Institute).
