planet.description: This planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team.

planet.name: HD 189567 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: WASP-75 b
1SWASP J224932.56-104031.8 b
planet.description: WASP-75 b is a transiting Hot Jupiter. Its radius is slightly inflated as compared to theoretical planet models with no core.

planet.name: HD 219415 b
GSC 4006-62 b
SAO 35261 b
2MASS J23145382+5643491 b
TYC 4006-629-1 b
planet.description: This planet was found by the Penn State-Torun Planet Search Team (PTPS) using the Hobby-Eberly Telescope. The planet is in a nearly 6 year orbit.

planet.name: Kepler-35 (AB) b
KIC 9837578 b
Kepler-35 b
planet.description: Kepler-35(AB) b is a planet orbiting two sub solar-mass stars which are in a binary (therefore the name with AB). The Kepler team estimates that approximately 1% of all close binary stars have planets. This yields a galactic population of at least several million.
planet.imagedescription:
This is an artists conception of the planet Kepler-35 b orbiting a binary star.
Illustration by Lynette Cook, http://extrasolar.spaceart.org.

planet.name: Kepler-20 b
2MASS J19104752+4220194 b
KOI-70
planet.description: The Kepler-20 system hosts at least five transiting exo-planets. Kepler-20 b has a period of only 3.7 days. Because it is about twice as big as the Earth, it is classified as a super-Earth or sub-Neptune. Kepler-20 b's composition is ambiguous. It could be a terrestrial planet with a rocky surface or it could have a significant gas envelope.

planet.name: Kepler-20 c
2MASS J19104752+4220194 c
KOI-070
planet.description: The Kepler-20 system hosts at least five transiting exo-planets. Kepler-20 c has a low mean density which means it cannot be composed of rocky and iron material alone but must have a gas envelope.

planet.name: Kepler-20 d
2MASS J19104752+4220194 d
KOI-070
planet.description: The Kepler-20 system hosts at least five transiting exo-planets. Kepler-20 d has a low mean density and cannot be composed of rocky and iron material alone. The planet has an equilibrium temperature of 95C (205F).

planet.name: Kepler-20 e
2MASS J19104752+4220194 e
KOI-070.04
planet.description: The Kepler-20 system hosts at least five transiting exo-planets. Kepler-20 e is most likely a rocky planet made of iron and silicates. It is approximately the size of Venus and is the first discovery of a sub-Earth size planet by the Kepler team. It is not habitable because the planet is on an orbit very close to its host star and the equilibrium temperature is as high as 1000 Kelvin (726C, 1340F).

planet.name: Kepler-20 f
2MASS J19104752+4220194 f
KOI-070.05
planet.description: The Kepler-20 system hosts at least 5 transiting exo-planets. Kepler-20 f is orbiting the star every 20 days and has a size similar to that of Earth. It is too close to the star to be habitable. However, it could have developed a thick water vapour atmosphere.

planet.name: HD 142245 b
planet.description: The star HD 142245 hosts a Jupiter-like planet. It was discovered as part of a Doppler survey at the Keck Observatory.

planet.name: HAT-P-40 b
2MASS 22220308+4527265
planet.description: HAT-P-40 b is a highly inflated hot Jupiter. It has been discovered by the HATNet collaboration.

planet.name: MOA-2010-BLG-477L b
MOA 2010-BLG-477L b
planet.description: Densely covered observations of a high-magnification event led to the discovery of the planet MOA-2010-BLG-477 b. Many different telescopes around the world have been used in this collaborative effort, including a 40cm telescope in Antartica.

planet.name: KOI-370 c
KOI-370 2
planet.description: This planet was discovered by the Kepler spacecraft. The planet is part of a multiplanetary system. Its planetary nature has been confirmed using transit timing variations which arise because the planets in one system pull on each other and slightly alter the transit times.

planet.name: KOI-370 b
KOI-370 1
planet.description: This planet was discovered by the Kepler spacecraft. The planet is part of a multiplanetary system. Its planetary nature has been confirmed using transit timing variations which arise because the planets in one system pull on each other and slightly alter the transit times.

planet.name: HD 85512 b
planet.description: The planet HD 85512 b could be potentially habitable if the planet exhibits more than 50 percent cloud coverage (Kaltenegger et al 2011).

KIC 8572936 b
Kepler-34 b
planet.description: Kepler-34(AB) b is a Saturn-sized planet orbiting two Sun-like stars which are in a binary (therefore the name with AB). The Kepler team estimates that approximately 1% of all close binary stars have planets. This yields a galactic population of at least several million.

planet.name: HD 159868 b

planet.name: HD 159868 c
planet.description: This planet was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Planet Search. It is orbiting a star previously known to host one planet. After the discovery of the second planet, the reported eccentricity of the first planet changed significantly. This system is an example of how multiple-planet systems can masquerade as moderately eccentric single-planet systems.

planet.name: Gliese 176 b
GJ 176 b
Gj 176 b
Gl 176 b
planet.description: Gliese 176 is a red dwarf located in the constellation Taurus. It has half the mass of our Sun. The planet consists mainly of rock but probably has a thick gas atmosphere.

planet.name: WASP-71 b
TYC 30-116-1 b
planet.description: WASP-71 b is a highly-irradiated planet which transits an evolved F8-type star every 2.9 days. The planet is larger than Jupiter but less dense.

planet.name: eps Corona Borealis b
HD 143107 b
HR 5947 b
HIP 78159 b
planet.description: Radial velocity measurements for eps CrB exhibit periodic variation of 417 days with an amplitude of 129 meters per second. The minimum mass for the planetary companion is 6.7 Jupiter masses.

planet.name: OGLE-2012-BLG-0358L b
planet.description: OGLE-2012-BLG-0358L b is a planetary mass object which is orbiting a brown dwarf. The discovery of this system suggests that planets can form around brown dwarf hosts, probably in a protoplanetary disk analogous to those around main sequence stars.

planet.name: HIP 78530 b
planet.imagedescription: This image shows the star HIP 78530 with its companion in the lower left corner. The companion's mass is most likely too large to be a planet. Credit: David Lafreniere (University of Montreal).

planet.name: HD 5891 b
planet.description: The star HD 5891 hosts a Jupiter-like planet. It was discovered as part of a Doppler survey at the Keck Observatory.

KIC 2571238 b

planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.description: This planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team. The scientific paper was published online in July 2013. The mean density of WASP-65 b is similar to that of Jupiter.

planet.name: HD 196885 A b
planet.description: The planet HD 196885 A b is orbiting a binary star in the constellation Delphinus. In 2004 a planet with an orbital period of 386 days was reported. A follow up study did not confirm the original planet but found strong evidence for a planet with a much longer period.

planet.name: Kepler-23 b
KOI 168.01
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. Its host star gets periodically fainter whenever the planet is in front of the star. Because there are multiple phenomena that can create a signal that looks similar to a planetary transit, the candidates have to be confirmed with another method. For Kepler-23 the planetary nature of the companions has been confirmed by transit timing variations, caused by other planets in the system, and a stability analysis. However, the mass of the planets is not well constrained yet and should be considered an upper limit.

planet.name: Kepler-23 c
KOI 168.02
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. Its host star gets periodically fainter whenever the planet is in front of the star. Because there are multiple phenomena that can create a signal that looks similar to a planetary transit, the candidates have to be confirmed with another method. For Kepler-23 the planetary nature of the companions has been confirmed by transit timing variations, caused by other planets in the system, and a stability analysis. However, the mass of the planets is not well constrained yet and should be considered an upper limit.

planet.name: HATS-2 b
GSC 665-00236 b
planet.description: HATS-2 b is the second planet discovered by HATSouth, a global network of autonomous wide-field telescopes. The transit light curves contain several anomalies, probably caused by starspots on the photosphere of the host star. The planet is on a 1.3 day orbit and only about 5 stellar radii away from the star.

planet.name: HD 28678 b
planet.description: The star HD 28678 hosts a Jupiter-like planet. It was discovered as part of a Doppler survey at the Keck Observatory.

planet.name: HD 13808 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: HD 13808 c
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: WASP-69 b
2MASS 21000618−0505398 b
planet.description: This planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team. It was published in a paper in October 2013.

planet.name: Gliese 433 b
GJ 433 b
Gj 433 b
Gl 433 b
planet.description: The star Gliese 433 is a red dwarf in the constellation Hydro. The radial velocity data shows an additional signal with a period of 10 years. However, due to a strong correlation with various activity indicators of the star, it is most likely due to a magnetic cycle and not a planet. The cycle is similar to the Sun's 11 year cycle.

planet.name: Qatar-2 b
GSC 04974-00112 b
2MASS J13503740-0648145 b
planet.description: Qatar-2b is a transiting hot Jupiter orbiting a K dwarf and was found by the Qatar Exoplanet Survey (QES). The radial velocity data shows evidence for a second companion with a period of about one year and a mass several times that of Jupiter.

planet.name: WASP-84 b
2MASS 08442570+0151361 b
planet.description: WASP-84 b is a sub-Jupiter mass planet in an 8.5 day orbit. Of the transiting planets discovered from the ground, WASP-84 b has the third longest period.

planet.name: HD 27442 A b
Epsilon Reticuli A b
planet.description: Epsilon Reticuli is a binary star system in the constellation of Reticulum. The secondary is a white dwarf star. The primary, an orange subgiant, is host to a Jupiter mass planet.

planet.name: HD 131496 b
planet.description: The star HD 131496 hosts a Jupiter-like planet. It was discovered as part of a Doppler survey at the Keck Observatory.

planet.name: HD 100777 b
planet.description: The star HD10077 is an orange subgiant star in the constellation Leo. A planetary companion was discovered in 2007 with the HARPS spectrograph.

planet.name: HD 106515 A b
planet.description: HD 106515A is part of a binary system. It also shows signs of a planetary companion. The star system is almost 11 billion years old.

planet.name: HD 18742 b
planet.description: The star HD 18742 hosts a Jupiter-like planet. It was discovered as part of a Doppler survey at the Keck Observatory. Special thanks goes to Andrew from the Punahou School in Hawaii who pointed out an error in the spectral classification.

planet.name: HD 79498 b
planet.description: The planet HD 79498 b was found with 65 radial velocity observations over 7 years with the 2.7m Harlan J. Smith telescope.

planet.name: HD 163607 b
planet.description: HD 163607 is a metal-rich G star with two planets. The inner planet has the largest eccentricity of any known planet in a muli-planet system.

planet.name: HD 163607 c
planet.description: HD 163607 is a metal-rich G star with two planets. The inner planet has the largest eccentricity of any known planet in a muli-planet system.

planet.name: HD 103774 b
HIP 58263 b
planet.description: The Star HD 103774 hosts a Neptune mass planet. The star shows signs for varying activity during the nine year observing campaign. The planet was discovered with the European HARPS instrument.

planet.name: HD 142 A b
HD 142 b
planet.description: The planet HD 142 A b is orbiting a G type star which is part of a binary. A second planet in the system has been discovered. After the discovery of the second planet, the reported eccentricity of the first planet changed significantly. This system is an example of how multiple-planet systems can masquerade as moderately eccentric single-planet systems.

planet.name: HD 142 A c
HD 142 c
planet.description: This planet was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Planet Search. It is orbiting a star previously known to host one planet. The star also has a stellar companion. After the discovery of the second planet, the reported eccentricity of the first planet changed significantly. This system is an example of how multiple-planet systems can masquerade as moderately eccentric single-planet systems.

planet.name: WASP-50 b
planet.description: WASP-50 b is a Hot Jupiter transiting a solar type star in the southern constellation Eridanus.

planet.name: HD 136352 b

planet.name: KIC 10905746 b
planet.description: This planet was not flagged as a potential planet candidate by the Kepler data pipeline. Citizen scientists discovered the transit simply by looking at many light curves by eye using the online tool at planethunters.org.

planet.name: HD 233604 b
planet.description: The 6 Jupiter mass planet HD 233604 b is one of the least distant planets to a giant star. The star shows a high 7Li abundance which may be either a sign of its early evolutionary stage or a recent engulfment of another planet in the system. The planet was found by the Penn State - Torun Planet Search (PTPS).

planet.name: WASP-64 b
1SWASPJ064427.63-325130.4
planet.description: This planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team.

planet.name: HD 20794 b
planet.description: The planetary system around the star HD 20794 consists of three super-Earths.

planet.name: HD 20794 c
planet.description: The planetary system around the star HD 20794 consists of three super-Earths. The planet HD 20794 c is the smallest planet signature detected so far (0.56 m/s) and might need further data to be confirmed.

planet.name: HD 20794 d
planet.description: The planetary system around the star HD 20794 consists of three super-Earths.

planet.name: Kepler-38 (AB) b
KIC 6762829
KOI-1740
2MASS J19071928+4216451
Kepler-38 b
planet.description: Kepler-38 (AB) b is a Neptune-sized planet orbiting a binary star (therefore the name with AB). The planet is not sufficiently massive to alter the orbit of the binary. Therefore one can only place an upper limit on the mass of the planet of 122 Earth masses.

planet.name: Kepler-11 b
planet.description: The Kepler-11 systems contains six transiting planets. The system was originally discovered by the Kepler telescope in 2011. The inner five planets make up a tightly packed system. A dynamical analysis revealed that the inner planets have a remarkably low density, lower than that of rock.
planet.imagedescription:
Kepler-11 is a Sun-like star around which six planets orbit. At times, two or more planets pass in front of the star at once, as shown in this artist's conception of a simultaneous transit of three planets observed by NASA's Kepler spacecraft on Aug. 26, 2010.
Image credit: NASA/Tim Pyle

2MASS 20124688+1806175
planet.description: HAT-P-34 b is a transiting planet that has been discovered by the HATNet collaboration. HATNet is a ground-based survey using standard telephoto lenses such as the Canon 11cm diameter f/1.8L.

planet.name: Kepler-51 b
KOI 620.01
KID 11773022
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered by the Kepler spacecraft. It transits its host star every 45.16 days for 5.7799 hours. Periodic transit timing variations confirm its planetary nature.

planet.name: Kepler-51 c
KOI 620.03
KID 11773022
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered by the Kepler spacecraft. It transits its host star every 85.31 days for 2.7849 hours. Periodic transit timing variations confirm its planetary nature.

planet.name: MOA-2008-BLG-379L b
planet.description: MOA-2008-BLG-379Lb is a planetary mass object discovered by gravitational microlensing. Because a faint source star crossed a large resonant caustic, the planetary signal dominates the light curve. A statistical model has been used to determine the physical system parameters.

planet.name: HD 38858 b
planet.description: This planet is part of a large data release by the Euopean HARP team.

planet.name: KELT-6 b
TYC 2532-556-1 b
BD+31 2447 b
planet.description: KELT-6b is a Saturn-mass planet transiting a metal-poor host star. The planet candidate was originally discovered by the KELT-North survey. Follow up observations confirmed the planetary nature of the candidate using a combination of photometry, high-resolution imaging, high resolution spectroscopy and radial velocity measurements.

planet.name: 81 Cet b
planet.description: The star 81 Ceti is a G-type giant in the constellation of Cetus.

planet.name: WASP-77 A b
1SWASP J022837.22-070338.4 b
planet.description: WASP-77 A b is a transiting Hot Jupiter (a planet similar to Jupiter but with an orbit much closer to the host star). It is orbiting a moderately bright G8 V star which is part of a visual binary. The binary has a separation of 3 arcseconds.

planet.name: 11 UMi b
planet.description: 11 Ursae Minoris is a star located in the constellation Ursa Minor and also named Pherkard or Pherkad Minor.

planet.name: WASP-60 b

planet.name: Kepler-33 b
KOI 707.01
KIC 9458613 b
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. Its host star gets periodically fainter whenever the planet is in front of the star. Because there are multiple phenomena that can create a signal that looks similar to a planetary transit, the candidates have to be confirmed with another method. The closely packed system Kepler-33 was validated by multiplicity (Lissauer et al. 2012). However, the mass of the planets is not known yet.

planet.name: Kepler-24 b
KOI 1102.02
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. Its host star gets periodically fainter whenever the planet is in front of the star. Because there are multiple phenomena that can create a signal that looks similar to a planetary transit, the candidates have to be confirmed with another method. For Kepler-24 the planetary nature of the companions has been confirmed by transit timing variations, caused by other planets in the system, and a stability analysis. However, the mass of the planets is not well constrained yet.

planet.name: KOI-1203 b
KOI-1203 1
planet.description: This planet was discovered by the Kepler spacecraft. The planet is part of a multiplanetary system. Its planetary nature has been confirmed using transit timing variations which arise because the planets in one system pull on each other and slightly alter the transit times.

planet.description: 51 Pegasi is a Sun-like star in the constellation Pegasus. The planet is also called Bellerophon.

planet.name: Kepler-61 b
KOI 1361 b
KIC 6960913 b
planet.description: Kepler-61 b is a 2.15 Earth-radii transiting exoplanet. It was confirmed using a statistical argument: It is 30,000 times more likely that Kepler-61 b is a planet than a blend scenario.

Artist's impression of the exoplanet Kepler-61 b.

planet.description: The star Gliese 832 is a star located in the solar neighbourhood in the constallation Grus. Therefore the observed planet Gliese 832 b is a good candidate for astrometric observations.

planet.name: TrES-3 b
2MASS J17520702+3732461
planet.description: The planet TrES-3 b has an orbital perdiod of just 31 hours and is undergoing orbital decay due to tidal effects.

planet.name: UZ For(ab) d
planet.description: UZ Fornacis is an eclipsing polar binary. High-speed photometry and archival eclipse timing data spanning 27 years suggest the presence of extrasolar planets (Potter et al 2011).

planet.name: OGLE-2011-BLG-0251 b
planet.description: The planet OGLE-2011-BLG-0251 b was discovered using gravitational microlensing. The host star is an M dwarf. It is located towards the Galactic Bulge. The planet lies beyond the snow-line, an important clue for planet formation models.
planet.imagedescription: This plot shows the light curve of the OGLE-2011-BLG-0251 microlensing event. The main magnification is due to the host star, only the tiny perturbation near the peak is the signal caused by the planet. Credit: Kains et al (2013).
